qas.question: How many basic vowel phonemes does Czech contain?
Where are three additional vowel phonemes found in Czech?
What are vowel sounds never reduced to when unstressed?
What a few exceptions where is the primary word stress in Czech?
What is stress unrelated to in Czech?
How many basic vowel phonemes are in English?
In English, where are three more phonemes found?

plausible_answers.text: The latter two diphthongs and the long /oː/

qas.question: What are exclusive to loanwords in English?
What are vowel sounds not reduced to when unstressed in English?
Where does each word usually have primary stress in English?

context: Czech contains <a0_0><b5_0>ten<b5_0/><a0_0/> basic vowel phonemes, and three more found <b6_0>only in <a1_0>loanwords<b6_0/><a1_0/>. They are /a/, /ɛ/, /ɪ/, /o/, and /u/, their long counterparts /aː/, /ɛː/, /iː/, /oː/ and /uː/, and three diphthongs, /ou̯/, /au̯/ and /ɛu̯/. <b7_0>The latter two diphthongs and the long /oː/<b7_0/> are exclusive to loanwords. Vowels are never reduced to <a2_0><b8_0>schwa sounds<b8_0/><a2_0/> when unstressed. Each word usually has primary stress <b9_0>on its <a3_0>first syllable<b9_0/><a3_0/>, except for enclitics (minor, monosyllabic, unstressed syllables). In all words of more than two syllables, every odd-numbered syllable receives secondary stress. Stress is unrelated to <a4_0>vowel length<a4_0/>, and the possibility of stressed short vowels and unstressed long vowels can be confusing to students whose native language combines the features (such as English).
